corpname.part: Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: Collection of audio recordings of folk festival concerts, workshops, and informal events, produced at various locations in Connecticut and Pennsylvania by the Indian Neck Folk Festival from about 1961-2015. The collection also includes papers, photographs, videocassettes, posters, and digital files.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into the following series: I. Manuscripts; II. Sound Recordings; III. Graphic Materials; IV. Moving Images; V. Optical Media; VI. Oversize materials. Arrangement reflects the intellectual/chronological order rather than the physical numbering of items.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Maya Lerman.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p:
A related collection is AFC 2016/055, Christopher Moore collection of Indian Neck Folk Festival and other recordings.
http://lccn.loc.gov/2016655337
. Collection of audio recordings of performances at the Indian Neck Folk Festival from about 1965-1972, as well as at concerts and informal folk music events in Connecticut, in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and the 1968 Old-Time Fiddlers Contest in Craftsbury Common, Vermont. Bulk of the recordings were made from 1964 to 1975, a few in 1982.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions

Collection is open for research; access to collection materials may be restricted. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at

altformavail.p: Selected analog recordings have digital preservation masters.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Indian Neck Folk Festival was founded by student members of the Yale University Folk Music Club, including musician John Cohen, and others. The festival was held in 1958, 1960, 1961, 1963, 1965, 1966, and then was held annually on a weekend in May. The group raised money for the festival by hosting a series of public folk music concerts on the Yale University campus and other locations. In 1970 the non-profit organization cut its ties with Yale, and moved the festival to a camp facility on Indian Neck Point in Branford, Connecticut. Jay Hartman-Berrier was the Indian Neck Folk Festival director for 51 years until her death in March 2017. In the early 1980s Jay Hartman-Berrier started a folk music concert series at Harrisburg Area Community College under the Indian Neck name, which ran for 5 years and then was taken over by the Susquehanna Folk Music Society. Because of her expertise and reputation, in 1983 she was approached by a group of five small colleges in Central Pennsylvania to organize the Pennsylvania Folk Festival, which ran for three years, showcasing Pennsylvania folk traditions, musicians and groups. The Indian Neck Folk Festival continued to be held during this time, by invitation only, in Falls Village, Connecticut. Since Hartman-Berrier's passing, the festival continues on with a different name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection of audio recordings of folk festival concerts, workshops, and informal events, produced at various locations in Connecticut and Pennsylvania by the Indian Neck Folk Festival from about 1961-2015. The collection also includes papers, photographs, videocassettes, posters, and digital files. The Indian Neck Folk Festival was an invitation-only folk music gathering held annually in May at a camp facility in Connecticut. The collection documents the relationships, activities, and music that this community shared over the course of several generations. Includes documentation about planning and organizing the Indian Neck Folk Festivals, as well as photographs and sound recordings of public concerts and events at Yale University, Harrisburg Area Community College, and the Pennsylvania Folk Festival. The Indian Neck Folk Festival and concerts featured various performers, including Bob Dylan, Dave van Ronk, Rev. Gary Davis, John Hammond, Big Joe Williams, Ian and Sylvia, Gordon Bok, Sara Grey, Kenneth S. Goldstein, Debby McClatchy, Helen Schneyer, Del McCoury and the Dixie Pals, Mike Seeger, Tony Trischka and Skyline, the Paton family, Mick Moloney and Eugene O'Donnell, Ed Trickett, Ann Mayo Muir, Stan Rogers, Utah Phillips, Sparky Rucker, John McCutcheon, Grey Larsen, Michael Cooney, Bill Staines, Joe Hickerson and Kathy Hickerson, Alistair Anderson, Kinvara, John Jackson, Sally Rogers and Howie Bursen, Barbara Carns, Philippe Bruneau, Lucy Simpson, Margaret MacArthur, Lani Herrmann, Pricilla Herdman, Jon Wilcox, Linda Goss, Elizabeth LaPrelle, Ken Perlman, and many others.

did.unittitle: Subseries A: Indian Neck Folk Festival

scopecontent.p: Documentation from the planning of the Indian Neck Folk Festival, including contracts, financial reports, scholarship fund information, board of directors information, room assignments for attendees, menus, festival invitations, newsletters, correspondence, and other information about the festival. From 1969-2015, the festival was held at Camp Isabella Freedman in Falls Village, Connecticut.

Location: Castle Hotel, Old Saybrook, CT. Includes letter of invitation to the festival from Jack Bertman. Includes pages from guest book with attendees names and contacts, as well as pages about lodging requirements for each attendee.
Location: Klar Krest Resort, Moodus, CT.
Location: Klar Krest Resort, Moodus, CT.

Documentation from concert series in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, hosted by Indian Neck Folk Festival group and the Harrisburg Area Community College Cultural Events Series.

Includes fliers, programs, press releases, and newspaper clippings about the Harrisburg Concert Series. Also includes grant from the Pennsylvania Council on the Arts, as well as contracts/agreements with performers.
Signed guest book from Harrisburg Concert Series.

Includes fliers, programs, press releases, and newspaper clippings about the Harrisburg Concert Series. Includes posters for Bill Staines, Gordon Bok, and Mike Seeger concerts. Also includes Pennsylvania Council on the Arts grant project description, schedule, and budget, as well as signed contracts/agreements with performers.

Includes fliers, programs, press releases, and newspaper clippings about the Harrisburg Concert Series. Also includes Pennsylvania Council on the Arts grant narrative and financial reports, as well as signed contracts/agreements with performers, such as Utah Phillips, Sparky Rucker, and Mick Moloney.

Includes fliers, programs, press releases, and newspaper clippings about the Harrisburg Concert Series. Also includes Pennsylvania Council on the Arts grant project description, schedule, and budget, as well as signed contracts/agreements with performers, such as Malcolm Dalglish, Larsen and Sutherland, Joe and Kathy Hickerson, and the Broken String Band.

Includes fliers and press releases about the Harrisburg Concert Series. Also includes Pennsylvania Council on the Arts grant project description, schedule, and budget, as well as signed contracts/agreements with performers, such as the Critton Hollow String Band and the Broken String Band.
Traditional folk festival planned by the Central Pennsylvania Consortium and held at Wilson College in Chambersburg, Pennsylvania.
Planning material and program/schedule for the first Pennsylvania Folk Festival in 1981. Includes photographs of the festival's performers, including Maggi Peirce and Bill Staines.

Programs, press releases, and newspaper clippings about the Pennsylvania Folk Festival in 1982. Includes invitation letter to festival from Jay Hartman-Berrier, as well as Pennsylvania Council on the Arts grant project description, schedule, and financial report.

Programs, press releases, and newspaper clippings about the third Pennsylvania Folk Festival in 1983. Includes invitation letter to festival from Jay Hartman-Berrier, as well as Pennsylvania Council on the Arts grant project description, schedule, and financial report, and narrative report of grant-in aid.

Programs, tickets, press releases, and newspaper clippings about fourth Pennsylvania Folk Festival in 1984. Includes invitation letter to festival from Jay Hartman-Berrier, as well as Pennsylvania Council on the Arts grant description and correspondence. Also includes performance contracts with festival performers.

Programs, tickets, press releases, and other materials about the Pennsylvania Folk Festival in 1985. Includes invitation letter to festival from Jay Hartman-Berrier, as well as Pennsylvania Council on the Arts grant description and correspondence.
Lists of names and contacts of craftsmen from Pennsylvania. Includes catalog from the National Handweavers' Show.
Articles and press materials for musicians, such as Maggi Peirce, Utah Phillips, the Boys of the Lough, and John McCutcheon.
Includes Gift Agreement for the Indian Neck Folk Festival collection, box-level inventory and inventory of physical media, and recorded media notes.
Includes container documentation for sound recordings from Indian Neck Folk Festival concerts and events. Information about song titles and performers is documented.

See Appendix A for more detailed information about concerts, performers, song titles, and instrumentation. Many of the sound recordings have been digitized and are accessible in the Folklife Reading Room. There are 249 additional digital audio files (WAV) in Series V: Optical Media.

Black-and-white and color photographic prints and negatives from the Indian Neck Folk Festival. Includes approximately 33 8x10 in., 112 5x7 in., 385 4x6 in., and 121 3x5 in. and smaller photographic prints. Also includes 54 film negatives. There are an additional 4453 digital still image files (JPEG) in Series V: Optical Media.
Black-and-white photographic print by Joe Alper. Indian Neck Folk Festival, 1961, Montowese House, Indian Neck Point, Branford, Connecticut.

did.unittitle:
Indian Neck Folk Festival photographs, mostly by Alan B. Schwartz,
1969

scopecontent.p: Black-and-white photographic prints mostly taken by Alan B. Schwartz. Includes photographs of musicians and performers, such as Gordon Bok, Tom Paley, Artie Rose, and Roy Berkeley. Backsides of photographs are labelled with performer names.

Black-and-white photographic prints mostly taken by Jay Smith. Includes photographs of musicians and performers, such as Roy Berkeley, Cliff Haslam, Jonathan Eberhart, Reed Martin, and Maggi Peirce. Backsides of photographs are labelled with performer names.

Black-and-white photographic prints mostly taken by Jay Smith. Includes photographs of musicians and performers, such as Archie Fisher, Hank Sapoznik, and Bob Carlin. Backsides of photographs are labelled with performer names.

Black-and-white photographic prints, negatives, contact sheet, mostly taken by Ken Feit. Includes photographs of musicians and performers, such as Pete Colby, Neil Rossi, and Helen Schneyer. Backsides of photographs are labelled with performer names.

did.unittitle:
Folk musician photographs and promotional materials,
ca. 1978-1985

scopecontent.p: Color and black-and-white photographic prints, promotional materials, articles, and biographies of folk musicians such as Sandy and Caroline Paton and Gordon Bok.

did.unittitle:
Folk musician photographs and promotional materials,
ca. 1978-1988

scopecontent.p: Color and black-and-white photographic prints and promotional materials for folk musicians such as Cliff Haslam, Joe and Antoinette McKenna, Rick and Lorraine Lee, Nowell Sing We Clear, the Tony Trischka Band, Bob Franke, Battlefield Band, and the Soldier's Fancy.
Black-and-white and color photographs of musicians, such as Joe Hickerson, April Limber, Bob McQuillen, and Pete Colby. Backsides of photographs are labelled with performer names.

scopecontent.p: Photographic prints of the Harrisburg Area Community College (HACC) concert series. Tony Trischka and band, January 23, 1982; Paton Family children's concert, February 20, 1982. Also includes photographs from the Pennsylvania Folk Festival, Wilson College, 1982.

From original folder: "May be Robin Sprung? Really unknown." Includes color photographs of musicians, such as Cliff Haslam, April Limber, Bob McQuillen, and Pete Colby. Backsides of photographs are labelled with performer names.

Photographic prints mostly taken by Joan Sprung. Includes photographs of musicians and performers, such as Helen Schneyer, Bob Clayton, and Maggi Peirce. Backsides of photographs are labelled with performer names.
